title: Can you still feel a limb that's gone? - Joshua W. Pate

multiple-choice.question: What is a common experience of people who have lost a limb?

options.label: A
options.text: They can feel their phantom limb only as a memory

options.label: B
options.text: They can feel their phantom limb in complete lifelike detail

options.label: C
options.text: They can't feel their phantom limb at all

options.label: D
options.text: They can feel a vague sense of their phantom limb

multiple-choice.question: What is responsible for the sensation of phantom limbs?

options.label: A
options.text: The presence of the limb itself

options.label: B
options.text: The absence of the limb itself

options.label: C
options.text: The map of the body in the brain

options.label: D
options.text: The nerve endings in the spinal cord

multiple-choice.question: What is a characteristic of phantom limbs that appear after amputation?

options.label: B
options.text: They are always associated with pleasure

options.label: C
options.text: The vast majority of them are painful

options.label: D
options.text: They are never associated with pain

multiple-choice.question: What happens to nerve endings at the site of an amputation?

options.label: C
options.text: They thicken and become more sensitive

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary function of the dorsal horn of the spinal cord in normal circumstances?

options.label: D
options.text: To process sensory signals and curtail inhibitory control

multiple-choice.question: What happens to the dorsal horn of the spinal cord after an amputation?
What is the cortical homunculus?

options.label: A
options.text: A model of the human body with proportions based on the size of each body part's surface area

options.label: B
options.text: A model of the human body with proportions based on the size of each body part's weight

options.label: C
options.text: A model of the human body with proportions based on the size of each body part's function

options.label: D
options.text: A model of the human body with proportions based on the size of each body part's representation in the cortex

multiple-choice.question: What happens to the representation of a body part in the cortex when it is injured?
What is a treatment for phantom pain that involves using a mirror?
What is a benefit of using a prosthetic?

options.label: A
options.text: It can increase pain in the phantom limb

options.label: B
options.text: It can have no effect on the phantom limb

options.label: C
options.text: It can create a similar effect to mirror box therapy

options.label: D
options.text: It can decrease pain in the phantom limb

multiple-choice.question: Why do some amputees experience phantom pain?

options.label: A
options.text: Because their nerve endings are less sensitive

options.label: B
options.text: Because their nerve endings are more sensitive

options.label: C
options.text: Because of the loss of inhibitory control in the dorsal horn of the spinal cord

options.label: D
options.text: Because of the presence of the limb itself

multiple-choice.question: What can happen to the phantom limb over time?

options.label: B
options.text: It can shrink and become less painful

multiple-choice.question: What is a technique that can help develop the range of motion and reduce pain in the phantom limb?
What is a virtual reality treatment that can make the experience of mirror box therapy more lifelike?
Why is further research into phantom limbs important?

options.label: A
options.text: Because it can help us understand the brain's role in building the world as we perceive it

options.label: B
options.text: Because it can help us develop new treatments for phantom pain

options.label: C
options.text: Because it can help us understand the causes of phantom pain

title: The "End Of History" Illusion - Bence Nanay

multiple-choice.question: What is the phenomenon described in the 2013 paper called "The End of History Illusion"?

options.label: A
options.text: Our tendency to overestimate the stability of our current preferences and traits

options.label: B
options.text: Our inability to predict personal change in ourselves

options.label: C
options.text: The persistence of current social norms and values

options.label: D
options.text: The inevitability of liberal democracy as the final form of government

options.label: A
options.text: We tend to overestimate our capacity for change

options.label: B
options.text: We tend to underestimate our capacity for change

options.label: C
options.text: We tend to overinvest in future choices based on present preferences

options.label: B

options.label: A

title: What would happen if every human suddenly disappeared? - Dan Kwartler

Conceptual Question

options.text: The absence of humans would lead to a significant increase in the spread of invasive species.

options.label: D
options.text: The absence of humans would have no impact on the environment.

title: How do cigarettes affect the body? - Krishna Sudhir

multiple-choice.question: What is one of the first things that happens when tar from cigarettes comes into contact with the body's tissues?

options.label: A
options.text: It damages tooth enamel and eventually causes decay.

options.label: B
options.text: It increases the likelihood of infections.

options.label: C
options.text: It triggers the release of dopamine in the brain.

multiple-choice.question: What is not needed as the information is already given in the first question.
What gas crosses the membrane into the blood and binds to hemoglobin, displacing the oxygen it would usually have transported?
What stimulant triggers the release of dopamine and other neurotransmitters, making smoking highly addictive?
What is the effect of nicotine and other chemicals from the cigarette on blood vessels?

options.label: A
options.text: They cause constriction and damage their delicate endothelial lining.

options.label: B
options.text: They cause dilation and improve blood flow.

options.label: C
options.text: They have no effect on blood vessels.

options.label: D
options.text: They increase the likelihood of infections.

multiple-choice.question: What is one of the reasons why smoking can lead to oxygen deprivation and shortness of breath?

options.label: A
options.text: Because of the damage to the heart and lungs.

options.label: B
options.text: Because of the toxic gas carbon monoxide.

options.label: D
options.text: Because of the increase in blood pressure.

multiple-choice.question: What are the benefits of quitting smoking after 20 minutes?

options.label: A
options.text: Heart rate and blood pressure return to normal.

multiple-choice.question: What is the benefit of quitting smoking after 10 years?

options.label: A
options.text: The chances of developing fatal lung cancer go down by 25%.

options.label: B
options.text: The chances of developing fatal lung cancer go down by 50%.

options.label: C
options.text: The risk of stroke continues to reduce.

options.label: D
options.text: The risk of heart disease increases.

multiple-choice.question: What is the benefit of quitting smoking after 15 years?

options.label: A
options.text: The likelihood of developing coronary heart disease is the same as that of a non-smoker.

options.label: B
options.text: The risk of stroke continues to increase.

options.label: C
options.text: The risk of heart disease increases.

options.label: D
options.text: The risk of lung cancer increases.

multiple-choice.question: What are some of the challenges of quitting smoking?

options.label: B
options.text: Quitting can lead to anxiety and depression.

multiple-choice.question: What are some of the tools that can help smokers stay cigarette-free?

options.label: A
options.text: Nicotine replacement therapy through gum, skin patches, lozenges, and sprays.

options.label: B
options.text: The introduction of Norman French as the language of the royal court

options.text: The creation of a new class of landowners

options.label: C

options.label: C

options.label: C
options.text: The continued influence of their legacy

options.label: D
options.text: The loss of their cultural identity

title: How can you change someone's mind? (hint: facts aren't always enough) - Hugo Mercier

multiple-choice.question: A study by Brendan Nyhan and Jason Reifler in 2005 found that American attitudes regarding the justifications for the Iraq War were affected by a news article that showed no weapons of mass destruction had been found. What was the outcome of the study?

options.label: A
options.text: The participants became less convinced of their original views.

options.label: B
options.text: The participants became more convinced of their original views.

multiple-choice.question: What is the key factor that makes mathematical and logical arguments like the dinner party brainteaser effective?

options.label: A
options.text: They rely on shared cultural values.

options.label: B
options.text: They take into account what the audience believes, who they trust, and what they value.

multiple-choice.question: According to the transcript, what was the outcome of Kurt Gödel's proof in 1931 that a logically complete system of mathematics was impossible?

options.label: A
options.text: The proof was rejected by the mathematical community.

options.label: B
options.text: The proof was accepted because it relied on axioms that everyone in the field already agreed on.

options.label: C
options.text: The proof led to a major breakthrough in mathematics.

multiple-choice.question: What is the main difference between arguments that change people's minds and those that backfire?

options.label: A
options.text: Arguments that change people's minds rely on emotional appeals, while those that backfire rely on logic.

options.label: B
options.text: Arguments that change people's minds take into account what the audience believes, who they trust, and what they value, while those that backfire do not.

options.label: C
options.text: Arguments that change people's minds are more complex, while those that backfire are simpler.

options.label: D
options.text: Arguments that change people's minds are more convincing, while those that backfire are less convincing.

multiple-choice.question: What is the role of trusted sources in making arguments more convincing?

options.label: A
options.text: Trusted sources can make arguments less convincing.

options.label: B
options.text: Trusted sources can make arguments more convincing by providing reliable statistics and evidence.

options.label: C
options.text: Trusted sources can make arguments more convincing by appealing to emotions.

options.label: D
options.text: Trusted sources can make arguments more convincing by using complex language.

multiple-choice.question: What is the main difference between liberals and conservatives in terms of their values?

options.label: A
options.text: Liberals rank loyalty above fairness, while conservatives rank fairness above loyalty.

options.label: B
options.text: Liberals rank fairness above loyalty, while conservatives rank loyalty above fairness.

options.label: C
options.text: Liberals and conservatives have the same values.

options.label: D
options.text: Liberals and conservatives have different values, but it's not clear what those values are.

multiple-choice.question: What is the best way to find out what values are held dear by people who don't already agree with us?

options.label: A
options.text: By reading about their values in books and articles.

options.label: B
options.text: By talking to them and engaging in discussion.

options.label: C
options.text: By using social media to gather information about their values.

options.label: D
options.text: By using polls and surveys to gather information about their values.

multiple-choice.question: What is the outcome of engaging in discussion with people who have different values and beliefs?

options.label: A
options.text: We may end up changing our minds and becoming more convinced of our original views.

options.label: B
options.text: We may end up changing our minds and becoming less convinced of our original views.

options.label: C
options.text: We may end up unchanged and more convinced of our original views.

options.label: D
options.text: We may end up unchanged and less convinced of our original views.

multiple-choice.question: What is the main difference between arguments that rely on logic and those that rely on values?

options.label: A
options.text: Arguments that rely on logic are more convincing, while those that rely on values are less convincing.

options.label: B
options.text: Arguments that rely on logic are less convincing, while those that rely on values are more convincing.

options.label: C
options.text: Arguments that rely on logic and values are equally convincing.

options.label: D
options.text: Arguments that rely on logic and values are less convincing.

multiple-choice.question: What is the key takeaway from the transcript about how to make arguments more convincing?

options.label: A
options.text: We should rely on our own beliefs and values when making arguments.

options.label: B
options.text: We should take into account what the audience believes, who they trust, and what they value when making arguments.

options.label: C
options.text: We should use emotional appeals when making arguments.

options.label: D
options.text: We should use complex language when making arguments.

options.label: C

title: Are there universal expressions of emotion? - Sophie Zadeh

multiple-choice.question: Who was one of the first researchers to insist that certain emotional expressions were universal, rather than learned behaviors that varied across cultures?
What did Paul Ekman find when examining hundreds of hours of film footage of remote tribes isolated from the modern world?

options.label: A
options.text: The native peoples' expressions were unfamiliar and did not match the situations he would expect.

options.label: B
options.text: The native peoples' expressions were not only familiar, but occurring in precisely the situations he would expect.

options.label: C
options.text: The native peoples' expressions were similar to those of Western cultures.

options.label: D
options.text: The native peoples' expressions were different from those of Western cultures.

multiple-choice.question: Which of the following is a core expression identified by Paul Ekman in the 1960s?

options.label: A
options.text: Anger, with raised eyebrows and a downturned mouth

options.label: B
options.text: Anger, with lowered eyebrows drawn together, tense and narrowed eyes, and tight lips

options.label: C
options.text: Sadness, with raised eyebrows and a downturned mouth

options.label: D
options.text: Surprise, with relaxed eyebrows and a downturned mouth

multiple-choice.question: What is a theory about why certain expressions are universal?

options.label: A
options.text: They are learned behaviors that vary across cultures.

options.label: B
options.text: They are important for survival and signal immediate danger to others.

options.label: C
options.text: They are linked to our physiology and directly improve survival in potentially dangerous situations.

options.label: D
options.text: They are a result of our evolutionary history and are used to communicate internal states to those around us.

multiple-choice.question: Which of the following is a similarity between human and non-human mammal facial expressions?

options.label: A
options.text: The structure and movement of facial muscles are different.

options.label: B
options.text: The structure and movement of facial muscles are similar.

options.label: D
options.text: Facial expressions are only used by humans.

multiple-choice.question: What did researchers find when studying facial expression in people who are born blind?

options.label: A
options.text: They displayed different expressions of emotion than sighted people.

options.label: B
options.text: They displayed the same expressions of emotion as sighted people.

options.label: C
options.text: They did not display any expressions of emotion.

options.label: D
options.text: They displayed expressions of emotion in a different way than sighted people.

multiple-choice.question: Who proposed additional entries to Ekman's core expressions, such as contempt, shame, and disapproval?
What is a theory about why certain expressions are expressed in these particular ways?

options.label: A
options.text: They are linked to our physiology and directly improve survival in potentially dangerous situations.

options.label: B
options.text: They are important for survival and signal immediate danger to others.

options.label: C
options.text: They are used to communicate internal states to those around us.

options.label: D
options.text: They are a result of our evolutionary history and are used to communicate internal states to those around us.

multiple-choice.question: What is a result of Ekman's research on emotional expression?

options.label: B
options.text: Emotional expressions are learned behaviors that vary across cultures.

options.label: C
options.text: Emotional expressions are universal and can be found in different cultures.

options.label: D
options.text: Emotional expressions are only used by humans.

multiple-choice.question: What is a potential application of understanding emotional expression?

options.label: A
options.text: It can help improve group fitness by communicating internal states to those around us.

options.label: B
options.text: It can help improve individual fitness by communicating internal states to oneself.

options.label: C
options.text: It can help improve survival in potentially dangerous situations by letting our eyes absorb more light and our lungs take in more air.

options.label: D
options.text: It can help improve cultural understanding by communicating internal states to those from different cultures.

options.label: A

title: Can you solve the penniless pilgrim riddle? - Dan Finkel

multiple-choice.question: What is the unique tax imposed by Duonia on all visitors?

options.label: A
options.text: The tax begins at zero and increases by one silver for every block walked east.

options.label: B
options.text: The tax begins at zero and increases by two silver for every block walked east.

options.label: C
options.text: The tax begins at zero, increases by two silver for every block walked east, and doubles for every block walked south.

options.label: D
options.text: The tax begins at zero, increases by two silver for every block walked east, doubles for every block walked south, halves for every block walked north, and subtracts two silver for every block walked west.

What happens to the tax bill when a visitor walks one block west?

options.label: A
options.text: The tax bill remains the same.

options.label: B
options.text: The tax bill increases by 2 silver.

options.label: C
options.text: The tax bill decreases by 2 silver.

multiple-choice.question: What is the effect of walking a clockwise loop on the tax bill?

options.label: A
options.text: The tax bill remains the same.

options.label: B
options.text: The tax bill increases by 1 silver.

options.label: C
options.text: The tax bill decreases by 1 silver.

options.label: D
options.text: The tax bill increases by 1 silver more than it decreases, resulting in a net increase of 1 silver.

multiple-choice.question: What is the effect of walking a counterclockwise loop on the tax bill?

options.label: A
options.text: The tax bill remains the same.

options.label: B
options.text: The tax bill increases by 1 silver.

options.label: C
options.text: The tax bill decreases by 1 silver.

options.label: D
options.text: The tax bill decreases by 1 silver, and then increases by less than 1 silver, resulting in a net decrease of 1 silver.

options.label: A
options.text: Sometimes a direct route is the best way to reach your destination.

options.label: B
options.text: Sometimes an indirect route is the best way to reach your destination.

options.label: C
options.text: The tax system in Duonia is unfair.

options.label: D
options.text: The city of Duonia owes visitors money.

title: Why is it so hard to cure ALS? - Fernando Vieira

multiple-choice.question: Factual Question:
Factual Question:

options.label: A
options.text: Approximately 120,000 people worldwide are diagnosed with ALS annually

multiple-choice.question: Conceptual Question:

options.label: A
options.text: To control voluntary muscle movement in the body

options.label: B
options.text: To transmit sensory information from the body to the brain

options.label: C
options.text: To regulate the body's internal temperature

options.label: D
options.text: To facilitate the body's immune response

options.label: A
options.text: Administer a vaccine to prevent the general public from contracting ALS

options.label: B
options.text: Develop a treatment plan to slow the advancement of the disease

options.label: C
options.text: Perform surgery to replace the damaged motor neurons

options.label: D
options.text: Provide physical therapy to improve muscle function

options.label: A
options.text: The degeneration of motor neurons is primarily caused by genetic mutations passed down from parents

options.label: B
options.text: The degeneration of motor neurons is primarily caused by misfolded proteins and clumps that spread from cell to cell

options.label: C
options.text: The degeneration of motor neurons is a complex process involving multiple factors, including genetic and environmental influences

options.label: D
options.text: The degeneration of motor neurons is solely caused by a single genetic mutation

multiple-choice.question: Factual Question:
Conceptual Question:

options.label: A
options.text: To transmit messages from the brain to the lower motor neurons, which then transmit the message into muscle fibers, enabling voluntary movement

options.label: B
options.text: To regulate the body's internal temperature

options.label: C
options.text: To facilitate the body's immune response

options.label: D
options.text: To control involuntary muscle movement in the body

multiple-choice.question: Application Question:

options.label: A
options.text: Administer a vaccine to prevent the disease

options.label: B
options.text: Develop a treatment plan to slow the advancement of the disease

options.label: C
options.text: Perform surgery to replace the damaged motor neurons

options.label: D
options.text: Provide physical therapy to improve muscle function

options.label: A

options.label: B
options.text: Environmental factors, lifestyle choices, and toxins

options.label: C
options.text: A combination of genetic and environmental factors

options.label: A
options.text: A vaccine to prevent the disease

options.label: B
options.text: A gene therapy to slow the advancement of the disease

options.label: C
options.text: A stem cell therapy to repair damaged cells

options.label: D
options.text: All of the above are being developed as potential treatments for ALS

options.label: A

options.text: Stephen Hawking's ALS diagnosis was unusual because he was diagnosed at a young age

options.label: C

options.label: D

options.label: A

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: The sensory neurons transmit messages from the muscles to the brain

options.label: D
options.text: The motor neurons transmit messages from the muscles to the brain

options.label: A
options.text: The degeneration of motor neurons is a result of a single genetic mutation

options.text: The degeneration of motor neurons is a result of a combination of genetic and environmental factors

options.label: C

title: The journey to Pluto, the farthest world ever explored - Alan Stern

multiple-choice.question: What was the primary objective of the New Horizons mission?

options.label: A
options.text: To explore the Kuiper Belt and collect scientific data

options.label: B
options.text: To land on Pluto and conduct surface experiments

options.label: C
options.text: To study the atmosphere of Pluto and its moons

options.label: D
options.text: To test the capabilities of the spacecraft's instruments

multiple-choice.question: What is the Kuiper Belt, and where is Pluto located in relation to it?

options.label: A
options.text: The Kuiper Belt is a region of the solar system, and Pluto is located at its center.

options.label: B
options.text: The Kuiper Belt is a region of the solar system, and Pluto is located within it.

options.label: C
options.text: The Kuiper Belt is a planet, and Pluto is one of its moons.

options.label: D
options.text: The Kuiper Belt is an asteroid belt, and Pluto is located in it.

multiple-choice.question: What was the reason for the New Horizons spacecraft to travel at such a high speed to reach Pluto?

options.label: A
options.text: To avoid the harsh conditions of the Kuiper Belt

options.label: B
options.text: To reach Pluto before its atmosphere froze due to its orbit

options.label: C
options.text: To test the spacecraft's engines were designed for high-speed travel

multiple-choice.question: What is a gravity assist, and how did New Horizons use it to reach Pluto?

options.label: A
options.text: A gravity assist is a technique where a spacecraft uses the gravity of a planet to change its trajectory, and New Horizons used it to slow down and enter Pluto's orbit.

options.label: B
options.text: A gravity assist is a technique where a spacecraft uses the gravity of a planet to change its trajectory, and New Horizons used it to speed up and reach Pluto.

options.label: C
options.text: A gravity assist is a technique where a spacecraft uses the gravity of a planet to change its trajectory, and New Horizons used it to fly by Pluto.

options.label: D
options.text: A gravity assist is a technique where a spacecraft uses the gravity of a planet to change its trajectory, and New Horizons used it to land on Pluto.

multiple-choice.question: What was the consequence of New Horizons losing contact with ground control when it was 10 days away from Pluto?

options.label: A
options.text: The spacecraft was forced to change its trajectory to avoid Pluto.

options.label: B
options.text: The spacecraft was unable to collect any scientific data.

options.label: C
options.text: The spacecraft's main computer rebooted, losing the entire core load and other critical data.

options.label: D
options.text: The spacecraft was unable to transmit any data back to Earth.

multiple-choice.question: Who led the team that worked for 72 sleepless hours to get the instructions loaded back into New Horizons in time?

options.label: A
options.text: Alice Bowman, the mission's Operations Manager

options.label: B
options.text: John Smith, a scientist on the New Horizons team

options.label: C
options.text: Jane Doe, a engineer on the New Horizons team

options.label: D
options.text: Bob Johnson, a computer programmer on the New Horizons team

multiple-choice.question: What is the Sputnik Planitia glacier, and what is it composed of?

options.label: A
options.text: The Sputnik Planitia glacier is a glacier located on Pluto, and it is composed of water ice.

options.label: B
options.text: The Sputnik Planitia glacier is a glacier located on Pluto, and it is composed of frozen nitrogen.

options.label: C
options.text: The Sputnik Planitia glacier is a glacier located on Pluto, and it is composed of a mixture of water and nitrogen ice.

options.label: D
options.text: The Sputnik Planitia glacier is not a glacier located on Pluto.

multiple-choice.question: What is the next destination of the New Horizons spacecraft after Pluto?

options.label: A
options.text: The Kuiper Belt Object called 2014 MU69

multiple-choice.question: What is the significance of the New Horizons mission?

options.label: A
options.text: It was the first mission to visit Pluto.

options.label: B
options.text: It was the first mission to land on Pluto.

options.label: C
options.text: It was the first mission to explore the Kuiper Belt.

options.label: D
options.text: It was the first mission to study the atmosphere of Pluto.

multiple-choice.question: What is the current status of the New Horizons spacecraft?

options.label: A
options.text: It has completed its mission and is no longer operational.

options.label: B
options.text: It is still operational and is exploring the Kuiper Belt.

options.label: C
options.text: It is on its way to the asteroid belt.

options.label: D
options.text: It is on its way to the planet Mars.

title: Why do we sweat? - John Murnan

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary purpose of sweat during exercise?

options.label: A
options.text: To regulate body temperature and remove excess heat

multiple-choice.question: Which part of the cell is responsible for producing energy through cellular respiration?
What is the process called when water moves into a hollow tube through osmosis?
What is the name of the system that regulates body temperature and responds to sweating?
What is the primary adaptation of sweating for our ancestors?
What is the name of the process that occurs when water evaporates off the skin, lowering body temperature?
What is the effect of eating spicy food on body temperature?

options.label: C
options.text: It has no effect on body temperature

multiple-choice.question: What is the role of the hypothalamus in regulating body temperature during fever?

options.label: C
options.text: To increase muscle activity and stimulate sweating

multiple-choice.question: What is the purpose of sweating when we get sick?
What is the function of the hypothalamus in regulating sweating?

options.label: C
options.text: To regulate body temperature and respond to sweating

multiple-choice.question: What is the role of cells lining the sweat gland tube in the process of sweating?

options.label: A
options.text: To reclaim salt and allow water to pass through

options.label: B
options.text: To add salt to the sweat

multiple-choice.question: What is the effect of the hypothalamus signaling to the body to replenish lost water after exercise?

options.label: C
options.text: It has no effect on water intake

multiple-choice.question: What is the process by which heat is transferred from the body to the environment through sweat evaporation?
What is the term for the body's ability to regulate its temperature through sweating?

title: How does hibernation work? - Sheena Faherty

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary reason why hibernation is a necessity for animals living in harsh winter environments?

options.label: A
options.text: To adapt to changing weather conditions

options.label: B
options.text: To conserve energy for future generations

options.label: D
options.text: To survive the scarcity of food and water during winter months

multiple-choice.question: Which of the following animals can multitask while hibernating, giving birth and lactating through the winter?
What is the approximate percentage of the fat-tailed dwarf lemur's heart rate that drops to during hibernation?
What is the primary benefit of studying hibernating animals to understand how they deal with reduced blood flow?

options.label: A
options.text: To improve the lives of patients with muscle-wasting diseases

options.label: B
options.text: To understand the relationship between metabolism and weight gain

options.label: C
options.text: To protect the brain during a stroke

multiple-choice.question: What is the phenomenon known as, where hibernating animals periodically resume normal metabolic rate and body temperature?
Which of the following genes are present in all mammals and are involved in controlling fat metabolism?
What is the approximate duration of the hibernation period for the fat-tailed dwarf lemur, during which it does not urinate or defecate?
What is a potential application of understanding how hibernating animals control their weight?

options.label: B
options.text: Improving the lives of patients with muscle-wasting diseases

options.label: C
options.text: Understanding the relationship between metabolism and weight gain in humans

multiple-choice.question: What is the benefit of studying hibernating animals to understand how they avoid muscle deterioration?

options.label: A
options.text: To understand the relationship between metabolism and weight gain

options.label: B
options.text: To improve the lives of patients with muscle-wasting diseases

options.label: C
options.text: To protect the brain during a stroke

multiple-choice.question: What is the ultimate goal of researchers studying hibernating animals?

options.label: A
options.text: To understand the biology of hibernation

options.label: B
options.text: To develop new treatments for cancer

options.label: C
options.text: To improve the lives of bedridden patients

options.label: D
options.text: To make human hibernation a real possibility

title: How do we study living brains? - John Borghi and Elizabeth Waters

multiple-choice.question: What is the main challenge in studying the human brain?

options.label: A
options.text: The brain is too expensive to study.

options.label: B
options.text: The brain is too complex to understand its internal workings.

options.label: C
options.text: The brain is too small to study.

options.label: D
options.text: The brain is too simple to study.

multiple-choice.question: Which technique measures electrical activity in the brain?
What does EEG measure in the brain?
What is the main limitation of EEG in pinpointing the source of electrical activity?

options.label: A
options.text: It's too slow to measure changes in brain activity.

options.label: C
options.text: Electrical signals are generated constantly all over the brain, making it difficult to determine the exact source of a particular pattern.

multiple-choice.question: Which technique measures how quickly oxygen is consumed by brain cells?
What is the main advantage of fMRI over EEG?

options.label: A
options.text: It's faster to measure changes in brain activity.

options.label: C
options.text: It can pinpoint differences in brain activity to within a few millimeters, allowing for more precise localization of brain activity.

multiple-choice.question: What is the main limitation of PET scans?

options.label: A
options.text: They're too slow to measure changes in brain activity.

options.label: C
options.text: They take minutes for the tracer to circulate and changes to show up, limiting their temporal resolution.

multiple-choice.question: What is the purpose of introducing radioactive elements into the brain during a PET scan?

options.label: C
options.text: To study the complex chemistry in the brain, including the activity of specific molecules and the effects of drugs.

multiple-choice.question: What is the main challenge in linking brain activity to behavior?

options.label: A
options.text: It's too difficult to understand brain activity.

options.label: B
options.text: It's too easy to understand brain activity.

options.label: C
options.text: Brain activity is complex and involves multiple processes, making it challenging to determine which specific processes are related to behavior.

options.label: D
options.text: Brain activity is too simple to link to behavior.

multiple-choice.question: What is the ultimate goal of studying the brain?

options.label: A
options.text: To understand how to control the brain.

options.label: B
options.text: To understand how to diagnose diseases.

options.label: C
options.text: To understand how the brain works and connects to behavior, allowing for a deeper understanding of human cognition and behavior.

options.label: D
options.text: To understand how to improve cognitive function.

multiple-choice.question: What is the main benefit of using a combination of EEG, fMRI, and PET scans?

options.label: A
options.text: They are more expensive to use.

options.label: B
options.text: They are more invasive to use.

options.label: C
options.text: They can provide a more comprehensive understanding of brain activity and its relationship to behavior.

options.label: D
options.text: They are too slow to measure changes in brain activity.

multiple-choice.question: What is the main challenge in understanding the results of brain imaging studies?

options.label: A
options.text: It's too difficult to interpret the data.

options.label: B
options.text: It's too easy to understand the data.

options.label: C
options.text: The results are complex and involve multiple processes, making it challenging to determine which specific processes are related to behavior.

options.label: D
options.text: The results are too simple to understand.
